But chances are their smartphone knows.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The leak of a Supreme Court draft opinion proposing to overturn <i>Roe v. Wade</i> raises a data privacy flash point: If abortion becomes criminal in some states, might a person’s data trail be treated as evidence?</p></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class=" b bh bc-gray-lighter mb-md hide-for-print" data-qa="subscribe-promo"><a class="pt-sm pb-sm flex items-center bold font-xxxs font-xxs-ns offblack hover-blue-bright justify-between" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/?itid=lk_cta_ssinline" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" style="border:none"><span class="mr-xs flex items-center"><span class="ml-xs">Help Desk: Technology coverage that makes tech work for you</span></span><svg class="content-box" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 16 16" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" style="transition:right .2s;position:relative;right:4px;fill:#666" aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" role="img"><title>ArrowRight</title><path d="M7.664 1.25l6 6a1 1 0 010 1.414l-6 6L6.25 13.25 10.499 9H2V7h8.585L6.25 2.664 7.664 1.25z" fill-rule="nonzero"></path></svg></a></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">There is precedent for it, and privacy advocates say data collection could become a major liability for people seeking abortions in secret. Phones can record communications, search histories, body health data and other information. Just Tuesday, there was new evidence that commercial data brokers sell location information gathered from the phones of people who visit abortion clinics.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“It is absolutely something to be concerned about — and something to learn about, hopefully before being in a crisis mode, where learning on the fly might be more difficult,” said Cynthia Conti-Cook, a technology fellow at the Ford Foundation.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">It is now common for law enforcement to make use of the contents of people’s phones, including location and browsing information. One case against an alleged Jan. 6 insurrectionist <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/04/02/capitol-siege-arrests-technology-fbi-privacy/?itid=lk_inline_manual_9">drew upon thousands of pages of data</a> from the suspect’s phone as well as Facebook records, prosecutors said.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">A major data source is our <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/12/31/how-we-survive-surveillance-apocalypse/?itid=lk_inline_manual_10">digital surveillance economy</a> — Facebook, Google and apps galore — in which companies track consumers to figure out how to sell to them. The data may change hands several times or seep into a broader marketplace run by data brokers. Such brokers can amass huge collections of information.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">That data is an easy target for subpoenas, or court orders, and many tech companies do not give straight answers about what information they would be willing to hand over. Google, for one, <a href="https://transparencyreport.google.com/user-data/overview?user_requests_report_period=series:requests,accounts;authority:US;time:2021H1&lu=user_requests_report_period">reports</a> that it received more than 40,000 subpoenas and search warrants in the United States in the first half of 2021.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-video" class=""><div><figure class="pt-xs mb-md mr-auto-ns ml-auto-ns hide-for-print
    ml-neg-gutter mr-neg-gutter"><div class="powa-wrapper" style="width:100%;height:0;background-size:contain;padding-bottom:56.25%;background-color:rgb(245, 245, 245);background-image:url(https://www.washingtonpost.com/player/prod/img/video-thumbnail-bg.png);background-position:center;background-repeat:no-repeat"></div><figcaption class="mt-xs mr-auto-ns ml-auto-ns left gray-dark font--subhead font-xxxs ml-gutter mr-gutter" data-qa="video-caption">A leaked draft opinion on May 2 shows that the Supreme Court is poised to overturn federal abortion protections. Here's what would happen. (Video: Joshua Carroll/The Washington Post)</figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Police and private citizens alike could buy data and use it to investigate suspected abortions. Phone location information has been used by activist groups to <a href="https://rewirenewsgroup.com/article/2016/05/25/anti-choice-groups-deploy-smartphone-surveillance-target-abortion-minded-women-clinic-visits/" target=_blank>target ads at people in abortion clinics</a> to try to dissuade them.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Crunching all that data isn’t easy, and law enforcement agencies have plenty of “lower-hanging fruit” to pursue, says Alan Butler, the executive director and president of the Electronic Privacy Information Center. Those more traditional methods include checking credit card records, collecting data from cellphone towers, and talking to friends and family members.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">But it is tough to predict how restrictive state abortions laws would become if <i>Roe v. Wade</i> were overturned. “Even a search for information about a clinic could become illegal under some state laws, or an effort to travel to a clinic with an intent to obtain an abortion,” Butler said.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">No matter what happens, the possibility of mass data-collection to enforce abortion bans will hang over the heads of people seeking abortions or helping others get them, said Nikolas Guggenberger, the executive director at the Yale Information Society Project. “People want to be on the safe side, so even if the law doesn’t apply to what they’re doing, it has a chilling effect,” he said.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">A number of groups have published citizen guides to avoiding surveillance while seeking an abortion or reproductive health care. Those groups include the <a href="https://digitaldefensefund.org/ddf-guides/abortion-privacy" target=_blank>Digital Defense Fund</a>, the <a href="https://www.reprolegalhelpline.org/internet-safety/" target=_blank>Repro Legal Helpline</a> and the <a href="https://ssd.eff.org/en/playlist/reproductive-healthcare-service-provider-seeker-or-advocate" target=_blank>Electronic Frontier Foundation</a>.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Here are three potential contributors to the data trail on people seeking abortions — and how they might be used.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="BAEULXFLVFA2LILGBGO6AIEPSQ"><div>Location</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Phones can collect precise information about your whereabouts — right down to the building — to power maps and other services. Sometimes, though, the fine print in app privacy policies gives companies the right to sell that information to other companies that can make it available to advertisers, or whoever wants to pay to obtain it.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">On Tuesday, <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/m7vzjb/location-data-abortion-clinics-safegraph-planned-parenthood">Vice’s Motherboard blog</a> reported that for $160, it bought a week’s worth of data from a company called SafeGraph showing where people who visited more than 600 Planned Parenthood clinics came from and where they went afterward.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">This kind of data could be used, for example, to identify clinics that provide abortions to people from out of state in places where that is illegal.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">SafeGraph CEO Auren Hoffman told The Washington Post on Tuesday that his company was discussing whether to stop offering aggregated data on physical traffic to abortion providers. SafeGraph and companies like it do not usually sell the location information linked to names or phone numbers, although the company has come under fire from privacy advocates before and has changed some of its practices to make it harder to tie data to specific people.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“You can find someone to say they can de-anonymize the data, but if it could be done, someone would have written a paper by now,” Hoffman said.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/07/22/data-phones-leaks-church/?itid=lk_interstitial_manual_32">A priest’s phone location data outed his private life. It could happen to anyone.</a></span></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">But privacy watchdogs say you can learn a lot by connecting the dots on multiple places a single person has visited. For example, last year, a Catholic blog obtained location information originally generated by the dating app Grindr to out a priest as gay. Those behind the blog were able to infer that a person at a church-related location also was visiting gay bars.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Apple and Android phones offer settings to turn off location services for individual apps — or entirely for the phone. But doing so might prevent the operation of certain functions, such as transportation apps.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="FB6OH2XS3RDFLC7Z44F6PTZSCI"><div>Search and chat histories</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Searching for information about clinics and medications can leave a trail of records with Google, which in some cases saves queries to a user’s profile.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">In 2017, prosecutors used Internet searches for abortion drugs as evidence in a Mississippi woman’s trial for the death of her fetus. A grand jury ultimately decided not to pursue charges, according to National Advocates for Pregnant Women. And last year, the Supreme Court of Wisconsin decided that detectives <a href="https://www.wicourts.gov/sc/opinion/DisplayDocument.pdf?content=pdf&seqNo=382720">did not violate</a> the rights of the convicted murderer George Burch when, operating without a warrant, they accessed downloaded data from his phone, including his Internet search history.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Private messages also can become evidence. In 2015, text messages about getting an abortion <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/01/magazine/purvi-patel-could-be-just-the-beginning.html?partner=slack&smid=sl-share" target=_blank>helped convict a woman</a> of child neglect and feticide.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">A 2020 <a href="https://www.upturn.org/work/mass-extraction/" target=_blank>report</a> by Upturn, a nonprofit organization focused on technology and justice, found that law enforcement agencies use “mobile device forensic tools” — which can give them access to Internet histories as well as to unencrypted emails and texts — when investigating matters as varied as marijuana possession and graffiti.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">People can take some steps to keep their search and chat histories private. Ford Foundation’s Conti-Cook said people do not have to volunteer their phones when police ask, and they can opt for <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/03/18/private-messaging-apps-browsers/?itid=lk_inline_manual_44">encrypted messaging apps</a> and a virtual private network, or VPN, to obscure their identities while conducting searches.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="XNBMNHVHUBCJDJML4IRS26XTFY"><div>Reproductive health apps</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Millions of people use apps to help track their menstrual cycles, logging and storing intimate data about their reproductive health. Because that data can reveal when periods, ovulation and pregnancy stops and starts, it could become evidence in states where abortion is criminalized.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">There is evidence that these companies play fast and loose with privacy. In 2019, the period tracker Ovia <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/04/10/tracking-your-pregnancy-an-app-may-be-more-public-than-you-think/?itid=lk_inline_manual_49">got pushback for sharing</a> aggregate data on some users’ family planning with their employers.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Last year, the <a href="https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/news/press-releases/2021/06/ftc-finalizes-order-flo-health-fertility-tracking-app-shared-sensitive-health-data-facebook-google">Federal Trade Commission settled with the period-tracking app Flo</a> after the app promised to keep users’ data private but then shared it with marketing firms including Facebook and Google.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">A recent <a href="https://www.consumerreports.org/health-privacy/what-your-period-tracker-app-knows-about-you-a8701683935/">investigation by Consumer Reports</a> found shortcomings in the way five popular period-tracking apps handle the sensitive user data, including sending it to third parties for targeted advertising.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" href="https://www.thelily.com/more-than-100-million-women-use-flo-a-period-tracking-app-heres-why-some-are-deleting-it/">More than 100 million women use Flo, a period-tracking app. Here’s why some are deleting it.</a></span></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">How are the apps allowed to share such personal data? Our interactions with health-care providers are covered by a federal privacy law called the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, or HIPAA. However, period-tracking apps aren’t defined as covered entities, so they can legally share data.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md"></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md"><i>Joseph Menn contributed to this report.</i></p></div><div class="mb-lg-mod hide-for-print" id="link-box"><div data-qa="content" class="linkbox-content"><h3 class="font-md font-bold font--headline offblack lh-md pb-xs" data-qa="linkbox-headline">Help Desk: Making tech work for you</h3><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/"><b>Help Desk</b></a> is a destination built for readers looking to better understand and take control of the technology used in everyday life. </p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>Go deeper:</b> <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/tech-your-life/">Tech in Your Life</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/tech-work/">Tech at Work</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/data-privacy/">Your Data and Privacy</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/internet-access/" target=_blank>Internet Access</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/whats-new/">What’s New</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/ethical-issues/">Ethical Issues</a></p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>Data and Privacy:</b> <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/interactive/2021/privacy-settings-guide/" target=_blank><b>A guide to every privacy setting you should change now</b></a>. But chances are their smartphone knows.","type":"text","originalIdx":1},{"_id":"5IZTWZT5YFGIJFIJSPQLDLKIUA","additional_properties":{},"content":"The leak of a Supreme Court draft opinion proposing to overturn \u003ci\u003eRoe v. Just Tuesday, there was new evidence that commercial data brokers sell location information gathered from the phones of people who visit abortion clinics.","type":"text","originalIdx":3},{"_id":"CHKV5RX6V5B53AXW65SKRTOLIE","additional_properties":{},"content":"“It is absolutely something to be concerned about — and something to learn about, hopefully before being in a crisis mode, where learning on the fly might be more difficult,” said Cynthia Conti-Cook, a technology fellow at the Ford Foundation.","type":"text","originalIdx":4},{"_id":"IW65Q3HNHVD45CO7KEKBMNW24Q","additional_properties":{},"content":"It is now common for law enforcement to make use of the contents of people’s phones, including location and browsing information. One case against an alleged Jan. 6 insurrectionist \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/04/02/capitol-siege-arrests-technology-fbi-privacy/\"\u003edrew upon thousands of pages of data\u003c/a\u003e from the suspect’s phone as well as Facebook records, prosecutors said.","type":"text","originalIdx":5},{"_id":"GJ65G7CCAJB73HAS7QE6B4GE6U","additional_properties":{},"content":"A major data source is our \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/12/31/how-we-survive-surveillance-apocalypse/\"\u003edigital surveillance economy\u003c/a\u003e — Facebook, Google and apps galore — in which companies track consumers to figure out how to sell to them. The data may change hands several times or seep into a broader marketplace run by data brokers. Such brokers can amass huge collections of information.","type":"text","originalIdx":6},{"_id":"UYQY7LCIIBGT7IBU4XCHFVUX3U","additional_properties":{},"content":"That data is an easy target for subpoenas, or court orders, and many tech companies do not give straight answers about what information they would be willing to hand over. Phone location information has been used by activist groups to \u003ca href=\"https://rewirenewsgroup.com/article/2016/05/25/anti-choice-groups-deploy-smartphone-surveillance-target-abortion-minded-women-clinic-visits/\" target=_blank\u003etarget ads at people in abortion clinics\u003c/a\u003e to try to dissuade them.","type":"text","originalIdx":9},{"_id":"UDK4JEH7WRHJ5DCULT2WQZGBNQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Crunching all that data isn’t easy, and law enforcement agencies have plenty of “lower-hanging fruit” to pursue, says Alan Butler, the executive director and president of the Electronic Privacy Information Center. Those more traditional methods include checking credit card records, collecting data from cellphone towers, and talking to friends and family members.","type":"text","originalIdx":10},{"_id":"2KFADEA26VCONBJWE6E32VSUYE","additional_properties":{},"content":"But it is tough to predict how restrictive state abortions laws would become if \u003ci\u003eRoe v. Wade\u003c/i\u003e were overturned. “Even a search for information about a clinic could become illegal under some state laws, or an effort to travel to a clinic with an intent to obtain an abortion,” Butler said.","type":"text","originalIdx":11},{"_id":"NTE455TNEFG43E6AVTYRNAJRSU","additional_properties":{},"content":"No matter what happens, the possibility of mass data-collection to enforce abortion bans will hang over the heads of people seeking abortions or helping others get them, said Nikolas Guggenberger, the executive director at the Yale Information Society Project. “People want to be on the safe side, so even if the law doesn’t apply to what they’re doing, it has a chilling effect,” he said.","type":"text","originalIdx":12},{"_id":"K7OOSMEIR5GJ7ISDFAM4JW5XNU","additional_properties":{},"content":"A number of groups have published citizen guides to avoiding surveillance while seeking an abortion or reproductive health care. Those groups include the \u003ca href=\"https://digitaldefensefund.org/ddf-guides/abortion-privacy\" target=_blank\u003eDigital Defense Fund\u003c/a\u003e, the \u003ca href=\"https://www.reprolegalhelpline.org/internet-safety/\" target=_blank\u003eRepro Legal Helpline\u003c/a\u003e and the \u003ca href=\"https://ssd.eff.org/en/playlist/reproductive-healthcare-service-provider-seeker-or-advocate\" target=_blank\u003eElectronic Frontier Foundation\u003c/a\u003e.","type":"text","originalIdx":13},{"_id":"UQ2EGXDR4JE6DHTFNBX4IF4OZY","additional_properties":{},"content":"Here are three potential contributors to the data trail on people seeking abortions — and how they might be used.","type":"text","originalIdx":14},{"_id":"BAEULXFLVFA2LILGBGO6AIEPSQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Location","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":15},{"_id":"NNTST3KJ5NASXG57PCOHAFS4SM","additional_properties":{},"content":"Phones can collect precise information about your whereabouts — right down to the building — to power maps and other services. Sometimes, though, the fine print in app privacy policies gives companies the right to sell that information to other companies that can make it available to advertisers, or whoever wants to pay to obtain it.","type":"text","originalIdx":16},{"_id":"NIVLIKCOYBEXLJEGCOFQNSQF7Y","additional_properties":{},"content":"On Tuesday, \u003ca href=\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/m7vzjb/location-data-abortion-clinics-safegraph-planned-parenthood\"\u003eVice’s Motherboard blog\u003c/a\u003e reported that for $160, it bought a week’s worth of data from a company called SafeGraph showing where people who visited more than 600 Planned Parenthood clinics came from and where they went afterward.","type":"text","originalIdx":17},{"_id":"IVMGAIILUFHD3HBFHSF7MP5WWI","additional_properties":{},"content":"This kind of data could be used, for example, to identify clinics that provide abortions to people from out of state in places where that is illegal.","type":"text","originalIdx":18},{"_id":"XSBDO2MOBVELJLFW72SO744ZFQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"SafeGraph CEO Auren Hoffman told The Washington Post on Tuesday that his company was discussing whether to stop offering aggregated data on physical traffic to abortion providers. SafeGraph and companies like it do not usually sell the location information linked to names or phone numbers, although the company has come under fire from privacy advocates before and has changed some of its practices to make it harder to tie data to specific people.","type":"text","originalIdx":19},{"_id":"3NXR337LTRHTBMD2CRKOBQELEA","additional_properties":{},"content":"“You can find someone to say they can de-anonymize the data, but if it could be done, someone would have written a paper by now,” Hoffman said.","type":"text","originalIdx":20},{"_id":"ZYOR4LDIQBC5DCCGDE3O7HX2EY","additional_properties":{},"content":"A priest’s phone location data outed his private life. It could happen to anyone.","type":"interstitial_link","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/07/22/data-phones-leaks-church/","originalIdx":21},{"_id":"GLVBR2SBMBA5LDM4IM4RC2HAAQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"But privacy watchdogs say you can learn a lot by connecting the dots on multiple places a single person has visited. For example, last year, a Catholic blog obtained location information originally generated by the dating app Grindr to out a priest as gay. Those behind the blog were able to infer that a person at a church-related location also was visiting gay bars.","type":"text","originalIdx":22},{"_id":"M7FDVFHBFVGI7MQHKVEVYMIK6I","additional_properties":{},"content":"Apple and Android phones offer settings to turn off location services for individual apps — or entirely for the phone. But doing so might prevent the operation of certain functions, such as transportation apps.","type":"text","originalIdx":23},{"_id":"FB6OH2XS3RDFLC7Z44F6PTZSCI","additional_properties":{},"content":"Search and chat histories","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":24},{"_id":"2HP2VG6CMZD5BDBPWJC4D7S3ZQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"Searching for information about clinics and medications can leave a trail of records with Google, which in some cases saves queries to a user’s profile.","type":"text","originalIdx":25},{"_id":"KD7RIOC4Q5EHXHBC4K5KSYI3NI","additional_properties":{},"content":"In 2017, prosecutors used Internet searches for abortion drugs as evidence in a Mississippi woman’s trial for the death of her fetus. A grand jury ultimately decided not to pursue charges, according to National Advocates for Pregnant Women. And last year, the Supreme Court of Wisconsin decided that detectives \u003ca href=\"https://www.wicourts.gov/sc/opinion/DisplayDocument.pdf?content=pdf\u0026seqNo=382720\"\u003edid not violate\u003c/a\u003e the rights of the convicted murderer George Burch when, operating without a warrant, they accessed downloaded data from his phone, including his Internet search history.","type":"text","originalIdx":26},{"_id":"YEMM76UHSJGDBKIHCJ5EBTFOBE","additional_properties":{},"content":"Private messages also can become evidence. In 2015, text messages about getting an abortion \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/01/magazine/purvi-patel-could-be-just-the-beginning.html?partner=slack\u0026smid=sl-share\" target=_blank\u003ehelped convict a woman\u003c/a\u003e of child neglect and feticide.","type":"text","originalIdx":27},{"_id":"LOZTSFQP2NH3FL5RYLJILL4PNY","additional_properties":{},"content":"A 2020 \u003ca href=\"https://www.upturn.org/work/mass-extraction/\" target=_blank\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e by Upturn, a nonprofit organization focused on technology and justice, found that law enforcement agencies use “mobile device forensic tools” — which can give them access to Internet histories as well as to unencrypted emails and texts — when investigating matters as varied as marijuana possession and graffiti.","type":"text","originalIdx":28},{"_id":"U3GOZ4VIA5GXBIZOTMGF7BBRO4","additional_properties":{},"content":"People can take some steps to keep their search and chat histories private. Ford Foundation’s Conti-Cook said people do not have to volunteer their phones when police ask, and they can opt for \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/03/18/private-messaging-apps-browsers/\"\u003eencrypted messaging apps\u003c/a\u003e and a virtual private network, or VPN, to obscure their identities while conducting searches.","type":"text","originalIdx":29},{"_id":"XNBMNHVHUBCJDJML4IRS26XTFY","additional_properties":{},"content":"Reproductive health apps","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":30},{"_id":"4M2I34MFVJHO3GNIS3GOFSLQ2I","additional_properties":{},"content":"Millions of people use apps to help track their menstrual cycles, logging and storing intimate data about their reproductive health. Because that data can reveal when periods, ovulation and pregnancy stops and starts, it could become evidence in states where abortion is criminalized.","type":"text","originalIdx":31},{"_id":"WFPFT7RU4FGYLAZBHHORKNQMLQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"There is evidence that these companies play fast and loose with privacy. In 2019, the period tracker Ovia \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/04/10/tracking-your-pregnancy-an-app-may-be-more-public-than-you-think/\"\u003egot pushback for sharing\u003c/a\u003e aggregate data on some users’ family planning with their employers.","type":"text","originalIdx":32},{"_id":"2WOUX4BHA5HDDLORJ36VCKOC6Q","additional_properties":{},"content":"Last year, the \u003ca href=\"https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/news/press-releases/2021/06/ftc-finalizes-order-flo-health-fertility-tracking-app-shared-sensitive-health-data-facebook-google\"\u003eFederal Trade Commission settled with the period-tracking app Flo\u003c/a\u003e after the app promised to keep users’ data private but then shared it with marketing firms including Facebook and Google.","type":"text","originalIdx":33},{"_id":"2EA3MMMN2VCIFI73WUHJYPFCNU","additional_properties":{},"content":"A recent \u003ca href=\"https://www.consumerreports.org/health-privacy/what-your-period-tracker-app-knows-about-you-a8701683935/\"\u003einvestigation by Consumer Reports\u003c/a\u003e found shortcomings in the way five popular period-tracking apps handle the sensitive user data, including sending it to third parties for targeted advertising.","type":"text","originalIdx":34},{"_id":"TJIQI2OGYREQPDPI36NLLIA25A","additional_properties":{},"content":"More than 100 million women use Flo, a period-tracking app. Here’s why some are deleting it.","type":"interstitial_link","url":"https://www.thelily.com/more-than-100-million-women-use-flo-a-period-tracking-app-heres-why-some-are-deleting-it/","originalIdx":35},{"_id":"F6HJH2NXORE3POQ2HTWBFBBO2M","additional_properties":{},"content":"How are the apps allowed to share such personal data? readabilityObject.title: Your phone could reveal if you’ve had an abortion
readabilityObject.content:
When someone gets an abortion, they may decide not to share information with friends and family members. But chances are their smartphone knows.

The leak of a Supreme Court draft opinion proposing to overturn Roe v. Wade raises a data privacy flash point: If abortion becomes criminal in some states, might a person’s data trail be treated as evidence?

There is precedent for it, and privacy advocates say data collection could become a major liability for people seeking abortions in secret. Phones can record communications, search histories, body health data and other information. Just Tuesday, there was new evidence that commercial data brokers sell location information gathered from the phones of people who visit abortion clinics.

“It is absolutely something to be concerned about — and something to learn about, hopefully before being in a crisis mode, where learning on the fly might be more difficult,” said Cynthia Conti-Cook, a technology fellow at the Ford Foundation.

It is now common for law enforcement to make use of the contents of people’s phones, including location and browsing information. One case against an alleged Jan. 6 insurrectionist drew upon thousands of pages of data from the suspect’s phone as well as Facebook records, prosecutors said.

A major data source is our digital surveillance economy — Facebook, Google and apps galore — in which companies track consumers to figure out how to sell to them. The data may change hands several times or seep into a broader marketplace run by data brokers. Such brokers can amass huge collections of information.

That data is an easy target for subpoenas, or court orders, and many tech companies do not give straight answers about what information they would be willing to hand over. Google, for one, reports that it received more than 40,000 subpoenas and search warrants in the United States in the first half of 2021.

Police and private citizens alike could buy data and use it to investigate suspected abortions. Phone location information has been used by activist groups to target ads at people in abortion clinics to try to dissuade them.

Crunching all that data isn’t easy, and law enforcement agencies have plenty of “lower-hanging fruit” to pursue, says Alan Butler, the executive director and president of the Electronic Privacy Information Center. Those more traditional methods include checking credit card records, collecting data from cellphone towers, and talking to friends and family members.

But it is tough to predict how restrictive state abortions laws would become if Roe v. Wade were overturned. “Even a search for information about a clinic could become illegal under some state laws, or an effort to travel to a clinic with an intent to obtain an abortion,” Butler said.

No matter what happens, the possibility of mass data-collection to enforce abortion bans will hang over the heads of people seeking abortions or helping others get them, said Nikolas Guggenberger, the executive director at the Yale Information Society Project. “People want to be on the safe side, so even if the law doesn’t apply to what they’re doing, it has a chilling effect,” he said.

A number of groups have published citizen guides to avoiding surveillance while seeking an abortion or reproductive health care. Those groups include the Digital Defense Fund, the Repro Legal Helpline and the Electronic Frontier Foundation.

Here are three potential contributors to the data trail on people seeking abortions — and how they might be used.

Location

Phones can collect precise information about your whereabouts — right down to the building — to power maps and other services. Sometimes, though, the fine print in app privacy policies gives companies the right to sell that information to other companies that can make it available to advertisers, or whoever wants to pay to obtain it.

On Tuesday, Vice’s Motherboard blog reported that for $160, it bought a week’s worth of data from a company called SafeGraph showing where people who visited more than 600 Planned Parenthood clinics came from and where they went afterward.

This kind of data could be used, for example, to identify clinics that provide abortions to people from out of state in places where that is illegal.

SafeGraph CEO Auren Hoffman told The Washington Post on Tuesday that his company was discussing whether to stop offering aggregated data on physical traffic to abortion providers. SafeGraph and companies like it do not usually sell the location information linked to names or phone numbers, although the company has come under fire from privacy advocates before and has changed some of its practices to make it harder to tie data to specific people.

“You can find someone to say they can de-anonymize the data, but if it could be done, someone would have written a paper by now,” Hoffman said.

But privacy watchdogs say you can learn a lot by connecting the dots on multiple places a single person has visited. For example, last year, a Catholic blog obtained location information originally generated by the dating app Grindr to out a priest as gay. Those behind the blog were able to infer that a person at a church-related location also was visiting gay bars.

Apple and Android phones offer settings to turn off location services for individual apps — or entirely for the phone. But doing so might prevent the operation of certain functions, such as transportation apps.

Search and chat histories

Searching for information about clinics and medications can leave a trail of records with Google, which in some cases saves queries to a user’s profile.

In 2017, prosecutors used Internet searches for abortion drugs as evidence in a Mississippi woman’s trial for the death of her fetus. A grand jury ultimately decided not to pursue charges, according to National Advocates for Pregnant Women. And last year, the Supreme Court of Wisconsin decided that detectives did not violate the rights of the convicted murderer George Burch when, operating without a warrant, they accessed downloaded data from his phone, including his Internet search history.

Private messages also can become evidence. In 2015, text messages about getting an abortion helped convict a woman of child neglect and feticide.

A 2020 report by Upturn, a nonprofit organization focused on technology and justice, found that law enforcement agencies use “mobile device forensic tools” — which can give them access to Internet histories as well as to unencrypted emails and texts — when investigating matters as varied as marijuana possession and graffiti.

People can take some steps to keep their search and chat histories private. Ford Foundation’s Conti-Cook said people do not have to volunteer their phones when police ask, and they can opt for encrypted messaging apps and a virtual private network, or VPN, to obscure their identities while conducting searches.

Reproductive health apps

Millions of people use apps to help track their menstrual cycles, logging and storing intimate data about their reproductive health. Because that data can reveal when periods, ovulation and pregnancy stops and starts, it could become evidence in states where abortion is criminalized.

There is evidence that these companies play fast and loose with privacy. In 2019, the period tracker Ovia got pushback for sharing aggregate data on some users’ family planning with their employers.

Last year, the Federal Trade Commission settled with the period-tracking app Flo after the app promised to keep users’ data private but then shared it with marketing firms including Facebook and Google.

A recent investigation by Consumer Reports found shortcomings in the way five popular period-tracking apps handle the sensitive user data, including sending it to third parties for targeted advertising.

How are the apps allowed to share such personal data? Our interactions with health-care providers are covered by a federal privacy law called the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, or HIPAA. However, period-tracking apps aren’t defined as covered entities, so they can legally share data.

Joseph Menn contributed to this report.
